unnormalised: Hey folks, some good news on the wildlife front! Remember the translocation project for the Gangetic River Dolphins near Varanasi? Well, Dr. Sharma from the Wildlife Institute of India is reporting a significant increase in dolphin sightings!
normalised: Hey folks, some good news on the wildlife front! Remember the translocation project for the Gangetic River Dolphins near Varanasi? Well, Doctor Sharma from the Wildlife Institute of India is reporting a significant increase in dolphin sightings!

unnormalised: Apparently, conservation efforts along the Ganges, including cleaning initiatives and stricter fishing regulations, are paying off. Local fishermen like Rajesh Kumar are also reporting larger fish catches, a win-win situation!
normalised: Apparently, conservation efforts along the Ganges, including cleaning initiatives and stricter fishing regulations, are paying off. Local fishermen like Rajesh Kumar are also reporting larger fish catches, a win-win situation!

unnormalised: But the work doesn't stop there. The Maharashtra Forest Department just announced a new Rs. 5 crore initiative to expand the protected area for tigers in the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. They're aiming to add another 50 sq km of buffer zone, offering more space for the big cats to roam and reduce human-animal conflict.
normalised: But the work doesn't stop there. The Maharashtra Forest Department just announced a new rupee five crore initiative to expand the protected area for tigers in the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. They're aiming to add another fifty square kilometer of buffer zone, offering more space for the big cats to roam and reduce human-animal conflict.

unnormalised: Plus, there's a fascinating study coming out of IISc Bangalore on elephant migration patterns in Karnataka. They're using GPS tracking to understand how elephants are adapting to changing landscapes and plan conservation strategies accordingly. It's great to see science and traditional knowledge, like insights from local tribal communities, coming together for conservation! Letâ€™s keep supporting these efforts.
normalised: Plus, there's a fascinating study coming out of I I S C Bangalore on elephant migration patterns in Karnataka. They're using G P S tracking to understand how elephants are adapting to changing landscapes and plan conservation strategies accordingly. It's great to see science and traditional knowledge, like insights from local tribal communities, coming together for conservation! Let's keep supporting these efforts.
